narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course expanded upon the concepts that were introduced in the first half of the semester and even displayed some very applied aspects of quantum mechanics in contemporary research as well.
Became very familiar with introductory quantum mechanics, and how to think about solving problem based on quantum mechanics models.
QM, wave function, electron density
Quantim

I learned the fundamental model problems of quantum mechanics (particle-in-a-box, harmonic oscillator, rigid rotor, hydrogenic atom etc.) as well as the mathematical tools for approaching these problems. Higher level theories were introduced including Hartree-Fock theory, Configuration Interaction, Coupled Cluster, and Active Space methods for computing electronic structure. DFT was also mentioned.
The fundamentals of quantum mechanics
Knowledge of angular momentum in quantum mechanics, variational theory, perturbation theory, and an introduction to Hartree Fock theory
In this half of the course, we covered: Angular Momentum, The Hydrogen Atom, Variation Method, Perturbation Theory, Electron Spin, Hartree-Fock Method

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Once again, I think this half of the course was very strong. I do think the lectures move a bit fast, but overall the problem sets were very reasonable and reinforced what we learned during class.
I don't think there is much to improve at all.

Sharon is reaaaaaaaally supper clear, and good at having people understand her. And I like her reviewing last lecture at the beginning of each lecture. 
Although the lecture doesn't give enough information, which is reasonable considering QM is something difficultI - I really hope Sharon can open another lecture to talk about QM in depth
Great prof

This course is very organized and exciting. The lecture notes are made available, are extremely clear, and add value. Prof. Hammes-Schiffer had one of her graduate students come and give computational demos to the class which made the math and theory more exciting and intuitive. The problem sets were also not too long, but gave necessary practice with key topics. A weakness of the course was that the most complex material was backloaded. We spent the first half of the term going over model problems that most students had seen before, and then did Hartree-Fock theory, CI, Coupled-Cluster, and DFT in about two weeks. I would have loved to get more into the modern quantum mechanical toolkit.

Strengths:
- provided most mathematical background
- emphasis on both physical and mathematical interpretations of concepts
- many example problems

Weaknesses:
- none

The class notes were well written and closely aligned with the textbook, which was a great reference for further study. I enjoyed the paper assignment and would be interested in learning a little more about applications in class. I think one weakness was the way the problem sets were assigned. In this second half of the semester, the problems certainly got more conceptually challenging compared to the math-heavy problem sets in the first half. I would rewrite the longer homework problems to be "guided" in such a way that provides hints, assumptions, or even a starting point for some parts. I think this would make learning the material a little easier and be of more benefit to the students. Also, I think similar to the first half of the semester, the second half should have its own math review file that goes over the main linear algebra concepts used (eigenvalues, matrix multiplication, diagonalization, etc).

The strengths and weaknesses of this course are very similar to those of the first half of the semester: it was great to have slides available before each class, in-class problems, and weekly assignments that weren't graded extremely harshly. Sharon and Mathew were very nice and helpful! It could be interesting to include a brief example of applications of the material at the end of each class, but we got to investigate this on our own in the paper assignment toward the end of the semester!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend this as an elective for a chemistry major. Regardless of where your interests lie, quantum mechanics is a foundation for so much of chemistry and being familiar with the concepts and having an idea of the methods is very important in contemporary research.
Yes. It's needed for pchem and theory.
Yes!!!!!!! Sharon is so clear! I like her a looooooot!
Grading can suck on homework
Only if you want to learn quantum mechanics for chemistry. If you want to just have some extra knowledge, you probably would get frustrated in the last half of the course because it's very technical.
Yes, quantum mechanics is a mind-expanding subject, and Professor Hammes-Schiffer does an excellent job at breaking down the fundamental concepts.
This course was a great introduction to some of the later concepts in quantum mechanics. Prof. Hammes-Schiffer is a straight forward instructor and focuses on the concepts.

I would recommend this course to another student because it was a welcoming introduction to quantum mechanics--the material was interesting to me--especially because it was similar to material that I felt I didn't fully grasp the first time around in PChem last semester--but didn't feel too crazy to learn thanks to good class notes and a reasonable pace.
